text:
The gap between India and China
with which India has
a rivalry of sorts is widening.

So what is it that's missing
institutionally and reform-wise?
Where are the lower hanging fruits?

Where can we put our, 
if you will,

thumb on the scale
to make things happen?
That is an outstanding question.
First, a frank admission.
In 1998, our investment was 0.68%
of GDP in R&D.
Today it is 0.68%

of GDP, although our GDP 
has gone up substantially.

There have been promises
made by successive leadership

to raise it to 2%, but 
that did not become possible.
That is number one.

Number two is that 
when you talk about 2%,
70% of it

or two thirds of it,
comes from industry.

One third of it comes from the 
government, like in China or Korea.
It is exactly reversed here.

So we must raise the 
share from industry.
There is no doubt about that.
And it is innovative

ways like the "New Millennium Indian
Technology Leadership Initiative," etc.

which help us in 
different ways to do it.

I think that's the second thing
that we must do

because education, research and innovation
are the currencies of the future

and very heavy investment 
in that is a must.
Of course, we always say that

per dollar that you spend, 
we give much more.

I have a way, because I am 
a traveling salesman for India.

I remember once 
when I created a table

and I looked at the number of scientific
research papers where we were very low

and then looked at scientific research
papers produced per dollar.
And we were right at the top.

China was number two, 
and the US was number three.

So that is why we have 
all these global R&D centers,
because we create

very high quality work - all these things.
But we should not rest on that.
In fact, I would turn the picture
sort of the other way around.

If you invest, therefore,
what a dollar is able to give in

India is ten times more than what
a dollar is going to give in Japan.

And therefore if we increase the number
of dollars, you can see how far we can go.
So that is the total mass.
